content.question: Let <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a differentiable function such that <math alttext="g of 10, equals, 2 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>e</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g prime of x, equals, 5 times e raised to the negative of the square root of x, power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the value of <math alttext="g of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 6.7: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and Definite Integrals

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
